header: This week, Neil -- the mastermind behind the CPAN PR Challenge -- draws our attention on another, new contest organized by Digital Ocean, where one can win a t-shirt by submitting at least 4 pull requests to Open Source projects. He even went above and beyond the call of duty, and provided an addendum to the official and shamefully Perl-devoid list of example projects for the contest. At the other end of the spectrum, Ribashushi is trying something novel: he's organizing a Tilt campaign that would enable him to work on CPAN projects for a full year -- beyond the obvious, it's also quite an interesting idea in the realm of Open Source founding, and I am rather curious to see how it'll develop. Enjoy! ~ `/anick
subject: Hacktoberfest

entries.text: Peter "ribasushi" Rabbitson. knowns (amongst other things) as the maintainer of DBIx::Class, has started a Tilt campaign so he could work a full year on CPAN projects.
entries.author: peter_rabbitson
entries.title: Year of ribasushi

entries.text: Want to be part of the crew behind the event? Here's your chance, YAPC::NA next organizer meeting is a couple of weeks away, and everybody who wants to lend a hand are welcome.
entries.author: dan_wright
entries.title: YAPC::NA 2016 Organizers

entries.text: Neil draws our attention to Hacktoberfest, a contest where you can get a t-shirt for submitting patches to at least 4 Open Source projects.  He also noticed that the official list of suggested Open Source projects is bereft of anything Perlish -- something he couldn't leave unfixed.
entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.title: CPANtoberfest - CPAN projects for hacktoberfest

entries.author: andrew_solomon
entries.title: State of the Geek 2015
entries.text: Geekuni did a survey on which programming languages its users are mostly working in, and which ones they wishes they'd use more. The results are in.

So Ricardo went ahead and upgraded a project stuck with a Catalyst of 2007 vintage. It is a shining badge of honor for the Catalyst crew that this  fast-forwarding through 8 years of development went admirably smoothly.
entries.author: ricardo_signes
entries.title: A big ol' Catalyst upgrade

entries.text: Gabor's report on his trip to Granada. His depiction of the local tapas alone makes me gnash my teeth and bemoans my absensce at the European YAPC.
entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.title: YAPC::EU 2015 Granada - hiking to Pico del Veleta in Sierra Nevada

entries.text: David gives us the highlights of what was new and hot on CPAN in September.
entries.title: What's new on CPAN - September 2015
entries.author: david_farrell

entries.title: I'm back...
entries.text: David is back from an acute bout of travelling, and he's now focusing on documentation. And, in that regard, he asks the floor the question: "what makes for good documentation?"

entries.author: olaf_alders
entries.title: Building your own MMDB databases for IP-specific data
entries.text: If you are dealing with GeoIP data for websites (or anything else, really), this article is for you. Olaf shows us how to create and query MaxMind's MMDB GeoIP database format.
It compiles Perl to Java, which can then call the JavaScript engine. Awe-inspiring or terrifying? I can't really tell.
entries.author: flavio_glock
entries.title: Perl5 to Java compiler - integrating with Rhino

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.title: Vagrant Perl Development Environment v1.1.0 released
entries.text: Not only it's a Perl Development Environment in a box, but Perl6's rakudo is also included. Nifty!
